newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian shares recover on renewed budget hopes.
newsitem.headline: Indian shares recover on renewed budget hopes.

text.p: ** (1245 GMT) - Indian stocks notch up smart gains as
bargain hunters step in on optimism 1997/98 that the
budget will survive crisis-wracked government
** Bombay's top shr index up 66.12 pts, two pct to 3,427.01
** Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda gets until April 11 to
prove majority in parliament
** Rally briefly interrupted by main opposition Bharatiya
Janata Party saying approval of budget unlikely before
trust vote, but market hopeful budget will survive
** National exchange index gains 2.90 pts to 970.15, Delhi
12.2 pts to 725.48 and Madras 31.46 pts to 3,370.83
Indian blue chips staged a smart rally on Tuesday as domestic funds and some foreign players bought during the dips in a day of wild swings wrought by the country's political crisis, dealers said.

"There has been a lot of buying by local institutions at lower prices," said Sanjeev Choithani, chief dealer at brokers Pashupati Advani. Funds bought after the Bombay index on Monday suffered its fourth largest plunge ever of 302 points.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's 10-month-old minority coalition government faces a confidence vote by April 11 after the Congress party on Sunday withdrew its crucial support.

"Our basic view is that the budget will remain intact," said Ajit Dayal, managing director of Quantum Financial Services, which advises foreign and domestic clients. "By and large there'll be no changes."

Analysts pinned hopes on parliament passing the 1997/98 (April-March) budget regardless of the political crisis. "There might be minor changes but we're hopeful the budget will go through," said Vinay Motwani at brokers KBS Capital Management.
The ruling coalition needs the support of lawmakers from the Congress party or the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, to ensure passage of the budget.
"The budget would not be possible before the confidence vote," BJP vice-president K.R. Malkani told Reuters. "I don't see how Congress or the BJP will agree with that."

But it could be considered later, Malkani said. "The government has to approach us then we can consider the matter," he said. "Let them convene a meeting. Let them do it properly," BJP president L.K. Advani told Reuters at the party office.

A spokesman for Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's United Front alliance said the coalition was exploring ways of ensuring the passage of the budget before the test vote. "We are making an effort," spokesman Jaipal Reddy said.
The NSE index rose 0.30 percent at 971.15 provisional close.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
